thread.title: Thousands shut out of Guns N' Roses concert in Wellington | Stuff.co.nz
thread.title_full: Thousands shut out of Guns N' Roses concert in Wellington | Stuff.co.nz

title: Thousands shut out of Guns N' Roses concert in Wellington | Stuff.co.nz
text:
Thousands shut out of Guns N' Roses concert in Wellington Last updated 18:45, February 2 2017 SUPPLIED 
The queues gathered on the walkway on Thursday night, shared by Nic Widfeldt on the Westpac Stadium Facebook page. 
Thousands of Guns N' Roses fans have been gathering in the rain outside Wellington's Westpac Stadium, unable to get into the show. 
Fans have been told there are technical difficulties, caused by the bad weather. 
Are you one of those stuck outside? Email us at Update: slight delay on gates open - we hope to have you inside soon. Thanks for your patience. #GnFnR â€” Westpac Stadium (@WestpacStadium) February 2, 2017 
Others said they had been told the turnstiles were not working. 
A security guard said on Thursday evening that crews were still preparing the stage, and their work had been delayed by the rain. 
The gates to the show were supposed to open at 5pm, but it took more than 90 minutes before they finally opened, and the queues begain moving. BRAD FLAHIVE/ FAIRFAX NZ 
Robert Lloyd, of Petone, was planning to head to the pub, rather than waiting in line for the gates to open. 
Support band Wolfmother were scheduled to start playing at 6.45pm, but the stadium was still largely empty. 
Angela Gillies-O'Flaherty wrote on the stadium's Facebook page: "It's now been over an hour standing in the rain and you still haven't opened the gates. This is such poor event management. 
"No doubt there is a health and safety risk with this many people - everyone - standing here." 
Brendon Gutschlag said: "Sort your technical difficulties out. It rains a lot in Wellington and if your system can't handle it that it is poor performance from your team. Ad Feedback 
"And a bit more information would be appreciated - one hour standing in the rain is not cool." 
Robert Lloyd, of Petone, said he would be meeting his mates at the pub, rather than standing in line outside the gates. 
"I'll be going hard once I'm in there." - Stuff
